title: Cisco: Only 13% have a solid AI strategy and they’re lapping rivals
optimized_headline: Only 13% of Companies Have Strong AI Strategies—Here’s Why They're Winning

raw_body:
If you’ve ever thought companies talk more than act when it comes to their AI strategy, a new Cisco report backs you up. It turns out that just 13 percent globally are actually prepared for the AI revolution. However, this small group – which Cisco calls the ‘Pacesetters’ – are lapping the competition. The third […]
The post Cisco: Only 13% have a solid AI strategy and they’re lapping rivals appeared first on AI News.
speedrun: A recent Cisco report reveals that only 13% of companies worldwide have a solid AI strategy. This group, labeled 'Pacesetters,' is significantly outpacing their competitors. While many companies discuss AI, few are prepared to implement it effectively. This finding highlights the urgent need for businesses to develop actionable AI plans to stay competitive in a rapidly evolving market.
why_it_matters: The 13% of companies with strong AI strategies could gain a significant market advantage, improving efficiency and innovation.
This disparity reveals a broader trend where organizations failing to adopt AI risk falling behind in their industry.

lenses.eli12: Cisco's report shows that only 13% of companies are ready for AI, meaning most are just talking about it. Think of it like a race where only a few runners have trained properly. This matters for everyone because businesses that embrace AI can offer better services and products, impacting daily life.
lenses.pm: For product managers and founders, the report underscores the importance of developing a clear AI strategy. The 13% who are prepared could meet user needs more efficiently, leading to higher satisfaction. This could mean prioritizing AI in product development to stay competitive.
lenses.engineer: The report highlights that only 13% of companies have a robust AI strategy, indicating a significant gap in readiness. This suggests that many organizations are not leveraging AI models effectively, which could impact performance benchmarks. Engineers should focus on building scalable AI solutions to help close this gap.
